STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR LANSING DIRECTOR
March 23, 2021
Kathleen Schultz
Wellspring Lutheran Services Kentwood
1715 Sutherland Dr. SE
Kentwood, MI 49508-5072
RE: License #: CB410201260
Investigation #: 2021C0112017 Wellspring Lutheran Services Kentwood
Dear Ms. Schultz:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 For repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan failed to achieve
compliance.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MSA and your
contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (616)552-3662.
611 W. OTTAWA  P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/lara  517-335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure
611 W. OTTAWA  P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/lara  517-335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE SERVICES
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB410201260
Investigation #: 2021C0112017
Complaint Receipt Date: 02/22/2021
Investigation Initiation Date: 02/22/2021
Report Due Date: 04/23/2021
Licensee Name: Wellspring Lutheran Services
Licensee Address: 4100 Pier N. Blvd Ste. A
Flint, MI 48504-1487
Licensee Telephone #: (989) 262-7386
Administrator: Kathleen Schultz, Administrator
Licensee Designee: Sean De Four, Designee
Name of Facility: Wellspring Lutheran Services Kentwood
Facility Address: 1715 Sutherland Dr. SE
Kentwood, MI 49508-5072
Facility Telephone #: (616) 281-4601
Original Issuance Date: 12/01/1991
License Status: REGULAR
Effective Date: 06/29/2020
Expiration Date: 06/28/2022
Capacity: Unknown
Program Type: CHILD PLACING AGENCY, PRIVATE
1

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Agency worker at CPA was attempting to coerce client into signing Yes
incomplete paperwork regarding parent contact.
Additional concerns that Supervisor was not following up on No
concerns appropriately or timely to include engaging youth in
counseling timely.
The parent did not get visits with child for 3 weeks. Yes
The agency was selectively following court orders. No
III. METHODOLOGY
02/22/2021 Special Investigation Intake
2021C0112017
02/22/2021 Special Investigation Initiated - Letter
Email response to complainant
02/22/2021 Contact - Document Received
Email from complainant with available times for a meeting outside
of her work hours
02/25/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Email to agency CA and Program manager requesting worker info
02/25/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Provided investigation allegations to CA and PM
02/25/2021 Contact - Telephone call made
Interviewed Parent A
03/01/2021 Contact - Document Received
Email from CA indicating that the case supervisor will be available
the following day
03/01/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Response to CA re: contacting assigned supervisor
03/04/2021 Inspection Completed On-site
2

Staff interviews completed by phone due to work from home
orders for CPA
03/08/2021 Contact - Document Received
Email exchanges with agency supervisor to obtain documentation
03/09/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Email to CA requesting personnel information
03/12/2021 Contact - Document Received
Rec'd requested documents from CA
03/12/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Scheduled exit w/CA for 3/19
03/17/2021 Inspection Completed-BCAL Sub. Compliance
ALLEGATION:
Agency worker at CPA was attempting to coerce client into signing incomplete
paperwork regarding parent contact.
INVESTIGATION:
On 2/22/2021 I received an on-line complaint written by Parent A alleging that Foster
Care Worker 1 (FCW1) showed up at her home one night after 9pm, while Parent A
was asleep, asking her to sign a form he needed for court the following day.
INTERVIEWS
Parent A - On 2/25/2021 I interviewed Parent A by phone. Parent A reported that
her children, Youth A and Youth B, were removed from her care on 10/9/2018. She
stated that FCW1 was initially assigned to her case, but she has since had two other
workers. She stated that FCW1 asked her to sign multiple blank documents while he
was assigned to her case including visitation forms and Parent Agency Treatment
Plans (PATP’s.) Parent A reported that FCW1 came to her home one night after
9PM and asked her to sign a PATP that she had never seen. She reported that
FCW1 stated that he needed her signature on the document for court the following
day and told her he would report that she was “non-compliant” if she did not sign.
She stated that she refused to sign until she was able to review the document along
with her attorney, which never happened. She stated that she couldn’t recall the
exact date that this happened, but it was her initial PATP. She stated that he
provided her with a PATP at another time that had been signed by the worker and
his supervisor several months prior. She reported that she did sign that PATP. She
reported that she wasn’t involved in any discussions or Family Team Meetings
(FTM’s) regarding the development of any of the PATP’s while CW1 was managing
her case, but she has been involved with case planning and has received PATP’s
timely since CW2 and subsequently CW3 were assigned to the case.
3

Supervisor 2 – On 3/4/2021 I interviewed Supervisor 2 by phone. She reported that
she did not supervise FCW1 and did not begin supervising Parent A’s case until
April of 2019 at which time CW2 was assigned the case. She reported that FCW1
and Supervisor 1 are no longer with the agency, so she does not have additional
information about Parent A’s allegations other than to indicate that CW2 had “a lot of
catch up to do” when she inherited the case.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
MiSACWIS – On 2/22/2021 I reviewed Parent A’s case file in MiSACWIS and
viewed the following documents:
 Initial Service Plan Parent Agency Treatment Plan (PATP 1) signed by CW1
& Supervisor 1 dated 11/26/2018
 Parent A’s signature not present
 No service plan development FTM documented
 Updated Service Plan Parent Agency Treatment Plan (PATP 2) signed by
CW1 and Supervisor 1 dated 2/18/19
 Parent A’s signature dated 4/23/19
 No service plan development FTM documented
 Updated Service Plan Parent Agency Treatment Plan (PATP 3) signed by
CW2 and Supervisor 1 dated 4/30/2019
 Parent A’s signature dated 6/24/2019
 No service plan development FTM documented
 Case Assignment history documenting that CW1 was assigned to the case
10/9/2018 until 4/5/2019 after which CW2 was assigned.
 Case Assignment history documenting that Supervisor 1 was assigned to the
case 10/9/2018 until 6/1/2019 after which Supervisor 2 was assigned
 Updated Service Plan Parent Agency Treatment Plan (PATP 4) signed by
CW2 and Supervisor 2 dated 7/2/2019
 Parent A’s signature dated 7/24/2019
 Service Plan FTM dated 6/25/2019
Personnel Records – On 3/12/2021 I received and reviewed the following
documents:
 Termination letter dated 4/12/2019 addressed to CW1 citing performance
concerns
 Performance Concerns and Duties Changes letter dated 7/2/2018 addressed
to Supervisor 2 citing performance concerns, which included:
 Failure to consistently follow through with assigned responsibilities
 Lax oversight of assigned staff
 Lack of consistent staff supervision
 Failure to provide good, consistent support & leadership to staff
 Performance Improvement Plan dated 2/22/2019 addressed to Supervisor 2
citing continued concerns, including”
 Inability to hold staff accountable
4

 Inconsistent and unpredictable attendance
 Lax oversight of assigned staff
 Performance Improvement Plan update dated 3/29/2019 addressed to
Supervisor 2 citing continued concerns, including:
 Failure to follow through with assigned tasks and responsibilities
ISEP 6.33(c) Assessments and Service Plans, Content (Commitment 69).
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if
of age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both
are not available or decline to sign the plan, the service
plan shall include an explanation of the steps taken to
involve them and shall identify any follow-up actions to be
taken to secure their participation in services.
ANALYSIS: While it cannot be established that CW 1 asked Parent A to sign
blank documents, the lack of her signature on PATP 1 supports
her allegation that she refused to sign without being given the
opportunity to review the document. Parent A’s signature on
PATP 2 was dated 64 days after the report date supporting her
allegation that she was not provided with the report for months
after it was completed. Additionally, Parent A’s signature on
PATP 3 was dated 55 days after the report date. PATP 1 and
PATP 2 were both completed by CW1. PATP 3 was completed
by CW2; however, CW2 had only been assigned to the case for
25 days prior to the report date. All three of the PATP’s were
approved and supervised by Supervisor 1. Additionally, PATP 4
was signed by Parent A 12 days after the report date at which
time the case was being managed by CW2 and supervised by
Supervisor 2 supporting Parent A’s allegation that she has been
provided with reports timely since CW1 was no longer involved.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2020 Renewal inspection dated 6/4/2020, CAP approved
7/21/2020
2019 Interim inspection dated 6/12/2019, CAP approved
7/1/2019
5

722-06B Family Team Meetings
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home
cases:
• Case service plan development
ANALYSIS: FTMs were not documented to have taken place for service plan
development of PATP 1, 2 or 3. PATP 1 and PATP 2 were both
completed by CW1. PATP 3 was completed by CW2; however,
CW2 had only been assigned to the case for 25 days prior to
the report date. All three of the PATP’s were approved and
supervised by Supervisor 1. A service plan development FTM
was documented to have occurred prior to the completion of
PATP 4 at which time the case was being managed by CW2
and supervised by Supervisor 2 supporting Parent A’s allegation
that she has participated in case planning since FC1 was no
longer involved.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
2020 Renewal inspection dated 6/4/2020, CAP approved
7/21/2020
2019 Interim inspection dated 6/12/2019, CAP approved
7/1/2019
ALLEGATION:
Additional concerns that Supervisor was not following up on concerns appropriately
or timely to include engaging youth in counseling timely.
INVESTIGATION:
On 2/22/2021 I received an on-line complaint written by Parent A alleging that Youth
A did not receive counseling services for 9 months despite CW1 being aware that
Youth A was self-harming.
INTERVIEWS
Parent A - On 2/25/2021 I interviewed Parent A by phone. She reported that, during
a visit with her daughter in November of 2018, she noticed cut marks on her
daughter’s arm. Parent A reported that CW1 also saw the marks and told Parent A
that he would “follow-up” on these concerns, but Youth A did not receive any
counseling services until July of 2019
Supervisor 2 - On 3/4/2021 I interviewed Supervisor 2 by phone. She reported that
she did not know the details of Youth A’s counseling prior to Supervisor 2 being
assigned to supervise the case in July of 2019 at which time she was engaged in
multiple counseling and support services. She reported that these services were all
put into place in May of 2019 after CW2 took over the case from CW1.
6

DOCUMENT REVIEW
MiSACWIS – On 2/22/2021 I reviewed the following in the case file:
 FTM dated 11/19/2018 documenting that Youth A would receive
counseling at school until her planned placement change, at which
time she would be referred to additional counseling services
 PATP 1 dated 11/26/2018 documenting that Youth A was in need of
counseling services, but it was “unclear what therapy service provider
would be appropriate given the uncertainty and possibility of placement
in different counties;” however, Youth A’s school counselor was
completing a referral to Kent Social Services Network to determine if
additional or more intensive mental health services were necessary
 PATP 2 dated 2/18/2019 documenting that Youth A was admitted to a
mental health behavioral stabilization home on 01/10/2019 after
verbalizing suicidal ideation
 PATP 3 dated 4/30/2019 documenting that Youth A was released from
the mental health behavioral stabilization program on 01/19/2019 with
a safety plan created by Network180 and recommendation for
continued weekly counseling with her school therapist
 PATP 4 dated 7/2/2019 documenting that Youth continues to
participate in weekly counseling with her school therapist, began
working with the Enhanced Foster Care Team on 5/20/2019, started
Trauma Focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy on 6/17/2019 and
participated in a trauma assessment on 7/2/2019
APPLICABLE RULE
MiSEP 6.20 p.24 Provision of Services (Commitment 70)
DHHS shall ensure that the services identified in the service
plan are made available in a timely and appropriate manner
to the child and family and shall monitor the provision of
services to determine whether they are of appropriate
quality and are having the intended effect.
ANALYSIS: Youth A received counseling and mental health services
throughout the entirety of the case as determined appropriate by
service providers.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
Technical Assistance is being provided regarding the use
of school counseling in place of mental health assessments
and community counseling services when it has been
determined that a youth could benefit from additional
services.
7

ALLEGATION:
The parent did not get visits with child for 3 weeks.
INVESTIGATION:
On 2/22/2021 I received an on-line complaint written by Parent A alleging that CW1
did not arrange for visitation with her children until 3 weeks after they were removed
from her care.
INTERVIEWS
Parent A - On 2/25/2021 I interviewed Parent A by phone. Parent A reported that
her children were removed from her care on 10/9/2018 but she did not get a visit
with them for 3 weeks. She reported that CW1 told her the agency policy was that
she could not have visitation with them the first week they were in care, but she
would be allowed to visit them at the agency after that. She stated that she did not
get visitation the second week either and CW1 told her that Youth A did not want to
visit with her, so she couldn’t visit with Youth B either.
Supervisor 2 - On 3/4/2021 I interviewed Supervisor 2 by phone. She reported that
there was a no contact order in place between Parent A and both youth at the
beginning of the case. She reported that the no contact order was in place for a
couple of months. After the no contact order was lifted, Youth A refused to visit with
Parent A, but Youth B started to have visits with Parent A. Supervisor A looked in
the MiSACWIS case file during our conversation and she reported that she was
unable to locate documentation of the no contact order, but she did see that a
parenting time exception regarding suspension of Parent A’s parenting time was
completed on 1/7/2019. Supervisor 2 stated that she would email me the preliminary
order indicating that parenting time was to be suspended when she next went into
the office. She also stated that she would look in the physical file for the no contact
order.
On 3/8/2021, Supervisor 2 sent me an email message with a court order attached.
Her email stated, “here is the first order – it says parenting time would be harmful to
the children. Once the no contact order was lifted is when it changed to ‘when
deemed appropriate’…” I reviewed the attached court order, which was an Order of
Disposition dated 1/3/2019. I responded with a request for the preliminary hearing
order, which she then sent along with order for removal. I requested a copy of the no
contact order she reported was in place at the onset of the case to which she
responded that she could not locate it in the physical file.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
MiSACWIS – On 2/22/2021 I reviewed the following:
 Case contact dated 11/1/2018 documenting parenting time between Parent A,
Youth A, and Youth B
 Parenting time exception completed on 1/7/2019 citing a needed therapist
recommendation regarding visitation
8

Court Orders – On 3/8/2021 I reviewed the following court orders:
 Order to Take Children into Protective Custody and Place dated 10/9/2018,
no mention of a no contact order
 Order After Preliminary Hearing dated 10/9/2018 which indicated that
“parenting time of Parent A was ordered to be supervised until further order of
the court.”
 Order of Disposition dated 1/3/2019 which indicated that parenting time with
Parent A “even if supervised may be harmful to the children.”
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-06I PARENTING TIME
Children under MDHHS care and supervision who have a
permanency goal of reunification must be provided
parenting time unless an approved exception exists see
Parenting Time Exceptions in this item. Parenting time
between the parent(s) and child(ren) is facilitated by the
supervising agency.
Frequency of parenting time must occur as indicated
below:
• Six years and older, visits occur, at a minimum, once per
week.
ANALYSIS: Parent A did not receive parenting time until 23 days after her
children were removed from her care, despite the preliminary
court order allowing supervised parenting time and there being
no parenting time exception requested or approved until
January of the following year.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
The agency was selectively following court orders.
INVESTIGATION:
On 2/22/2021 I received an on-line complaint written by Parent A alleging that
agency staff were selectively following court orders. No specifics were provided.
INTERVIEWS
Parent A - On 2/25/2021 I interviewed Parent A by phone. She reported that Youth
A was placed with her dad, Parent B, without a court order allowing them to do so.
She stated that Supervisor A sent threatening text messages to her mother, with
whom Youth A was placed, stating that Youth A would be moved to another home if
9

Parent A’s mother didn’t do what Supervisor 1 wanted. Parent A stated that she
believes Supervisor 1 moved Youth A to Parent B’s home as retaliation. Parent A
stated that she would send me copies of the text messages for me to review;
however, I have not received them.
Youth A subsequently ran away from Parent A’s mother home after which the
agency placed Youth A in Parent B’s home. Parent A stated that Youth A was in
Parent B’s home for 3 weeks before an “emergency hearing” was held ordering
placement into Parent B’s home.
Supervisor 1 - On 3/4/2021 I interviewed Supervisor 1 by phone. Supervisor 1
denied threatening Parent A’s mother but stated that they did have a text exchange
about her unwillingness to provide transportation for Youth A despite this being
previously agreed upon and that if she didn’t follow policies, Youth A would have to
move.
Supervisor 1 stated that the agency had a court order in place at the time Youth A
was placed in Parent B’s home which gave them authority to make the placement.
She stated that the placement was made due to Youth A no longer wanting to be in
Parent A’s mother’s home stating that she was too much like Parent A.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
MiSACWIS – On 3/4/2021 I reviewed the following documentation:
 Youth A’s placement history documenting placement with Parent B on
11/2/2020
 Updated Service Plan dated 11/5/2020 which documented that, on
10/14/2020 Parent A’s mother, with whom Youth A was placed stated that
Youth A was not allowed back in her home. Youth A then went on an
extended home visit with Parent B and was subsequently placed in his care
on 11/2/2020
 Parent Agency Treatment Plan dated 11/5/2020 which documented Parent
B’s last dirty drug screen was dated 10/13/3030 and that Kent Reunification
Program started on 11/2/2020
Court Orders – I reviewed the Order After Dispositional Review/Permanency
Planning Hearing dated 9/30/2020 ordering that Youth A may have unsupervised
visits with Parent B. It was also ordered that Youth A may be released to Parent B
upon Parent B providing clean drug screens and a reunification program being in
place.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 722-07B PERMANENCY PLANNING - REUNIFICATION
CASEWORKER RESPONSIBILITIES IN REUNIFICATION
Prior to returning a child to the home from which he/she
was removed or to the home of the other parent, the
caseworker must:
10

 Determine the motivation and capability of the parent or
legal guardian to provide for the ongoing safety and well
being of the child.
 Consider whether return home would cause a substantial
risk of harm to the child's life, physical health or mental
well-being. When the child is placed within his/her
parent's home, the court must make a written finding that
the “Conditions of the placement are adequate to
safeguard the child from the risk of harm to the child's
life, physical health or mental well-being.”
 Provide documentation that appropriate rehabilitative,
remedial services have been consistently provided to the
parent, other relevant adults in the home, and the child to
minimize the potential for further abuse or neglect.
Overall, barrier reduction must be either partial or
substantial. Collateral resources from service providers
must be utilized in helping the caseworker arrive at a
decision to return the child home. Documentation of
collateral contact results is to be entered in the case
service plan. Include a statement in the case service plan
that a decision to return the child home has been
reviewed and agreed upon by the supervisor.
ANALYSIS: The agency staff had authority by court order to allow
unsupervised visitation and the subsequent placement of Youth
A in Parent B’s home.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable CAP, I recommend no change in the license status.
11

3/19/2021
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant

12
